response.answer_text: Homeopathy isn’t even a science. Brief (if not 100% accurate) summary: The scientific method is based on testing the validity of hypotheses: by rigorously testing them in such a way that they can be disproved or proved, whilst ensuring all other confounding factors are excluded, and using large enough data sets that any random variations become insignificant. This evidence basis is what modern medicine is mostly based on. The homeopathic method is based on the following principles: That like cures like - a substance causing effects “similar” to one’s symptoms should cure it.That dilution of said curative agent will increase the potency of its effects - that water has a “memory”.This belief in water having a memory extends to water “remembering” things such as exposure to Xrays or sunlight, prior to dilution. Sometimes even the dreams of the homeopath preparing the dilution!Selection from a formulary based on the person’s life history, balance of humours, even star signs.That disease is caused by miasma.Do any of those look like application of the scientific method, or even the theories established through scientific method? That should be your answer straight away.  But let’s see if we can apply scientific method to see if the treatments have any merit? homeopathy The Cochrane foundation review all studies pertaining to a certain question, evaluate the strength of said studies, and utilises the highest quality evidence to come to a conclusion. And unfortunately, these studies find that the only evidence in support of homeopathy is of poor quality, meaning that the effects of homeopathy can’t truly be proven to be distinguishable from uncontrolled variables, or placebo.  So I would suggest if you want to prove or disprove it, construct some high quality randomised controlled trials into the effects of homeopathy versus placebo, and see whether they disprove the hypothesis that homeopathy is no different to placebo.

Q. Is Homeopathy a Pseudoscience?  (1) Short answer: Yes, because it does not meet the rigor of the Scientific method, and Falsifiability.Its effect is often equated to the ‘Placebo Effect’.That said, it can bring real comfort to patients.Questions on the standing of homeopathy, just like questions on economics and Psychoanalysis, are not best answered by reaching for a single criteria to demarcate science and pseudoscience.(2) What is homeopathy? Homeopathic medicines are created, for the most part, by taking small quantities of plants and minerals, which are then repeatedly diluted in water, shaken vigorously, diluted again, before being added to sugar pills. The substances are selected using the hypothesis ‘like cures like’. If a substance would harm you in high concentration, the same substance in an exceptionally weak dosage will fight those very symptoms. Smallpox was initially controlled by deliberately placing infectious material from smallpox pustules into a scratch in a healthy person’s skin, as inoculation. So, the ‘like cures like’ principle is not so obviously absurd. But, homeopathic treatments are diluted and re-diluted so many times that we should often expect there to be no molecules of the supposedly therapeutic substance present. Is it a mere sugar pill backed by an interesting back-story? (3) Testing, but against what? Forget homeopathy for now. Let’s discuss the testing basis for mainstream pharmaceuticals. There is an existing ailment. The existing established medicine is X. A new, supposedly improved, medicine Y, is to be tested. The standard pharma industry regime is to test a new medicine against a placebo.When X originally came on, it was tested against a placebo.X became ‘standard treatment’.Y came on new.Per pharma process, Y tested against a placebo.But, should Y be tested against X instead? Y is supposed to be better than X.If both X and Y are available in the pharma market, a doctor has to decide which to prescribe to a patient. How will the doctor know this if Y was never tested against X?Trials of new medicines (Y) compared against ‘standard treatment’ (X), is more expensive to conduct than placebo-controlled trials. The number of test participants need to be higher, in order to get a more meaningful statistical result.It’s also much easier to produce a new drug (Y) that is better over the placebo, than a ‘standard treatment’ (X).Self-evidently, pharma companies favor trials against placebo.(4) Testing basis for Complementary and Alternative medicine We’re talking about homeopathy, acupuncture, aromatherapy, herbalism, etc. (4a) Issue #1: No placebo-equivalent test For homeopathy, there could be a placebo-controlled test. But, what about massage therapy for a neck ailment? What is the placebo equivalent test? A pressureless massage? Do we dismiss a treatment because we can’t design a suitable test-placebo? Are we missing out on anything? (4b) Issue #2: How to test holistic treatment? In mainstream medicine, we’re familiar that depression is treated with Prozac (Fluoxetine). High cholesterol, Lipitor (Atorvastatin). But, what if a doctor doesn’t assign a type of medicine to a type of disease condition. But instead, attempts to evaluate the overall situation of the patient. Suppose the doctor claims that symptoms, biography, lifestyle all interact in complex ways, and offers the patient a customized blend of medicines, exercise, diet, etc on the conviction that these act in a synergistic, integrated way on the patient as a whole. How do we setup a clinical trial for this, that involve idiosyncrasies of individual patients? Do we dismiss a treatment because we can’t design a suitable trial? Are we missing out on anything? In homeopathy, treatment is usually tailored to the individual. A homeopathic prescription is based not only on the symptoms of the disease, but also on a host of other factors particular to the patient such as lifestyle, emotional health, personality, eating habits, medical history. Homeopathic practitioners are exercising their judgment in concentrating on the needs of the patients as individuals, rather than adopting a the ‘cookbook’ approach. (5) Placebo Effect The process of trialling new treatments against a placebo can encourage us to write-off the placebo effect as insignificant. But, the placebo effect is not negligible, nor is it uniform. Taking a sugar pill can make someone feel better.Taking 4 can make them feel better still.The intensity of the placebo delivery correlates with its efficacy. An injection of a placebo saline solution, being invasive, gives an even stronger effect than swallowing 4 pills.Large pills seem to have greater effect than small pills.Capsules more effective than tablets.Many patients trust their doctors instinctively. They ‘leave it to the doctor’ to treat them, mildly interested in the medical processes.The very processes of conversation, consultation with a doctor also seem to be effective in relieving ill-health. The more elaborate and formalized the processes, the stronger the beneficial outcomes.

Homeopathy is a pseudo-science because it is necessary for conventional medicine to present it as such. Yet in order to be able to present it as a pseudo-science several important observable facts have to be strenuously avoided by those who support the pharmaceutical drugs industry. First. Homeopathy has been treating patients successfully for over 220 years, almost entirely without the financial support of governments. Homeopathic patients have this annoying habit of getting better, and so they return to homeopathy when they become sick again. Mention this and medical science cries in alarm - “Anecdotal” - “Unscientific” - “Placebo” - et al. They do not want too many people to notice. Second. To support the idea that homeopathy is a pseudo-science, a therapy for which there is no scientific evidence, medical fundamentalists have to ignore a sizeable and growing number of scientific studies that have found homeopathy to be more effective than placebo, and/or pharmaceutical drugs. They don’t meet some of the (usually spurious) scientific criteria imposed on research into homeopathy, criteria that (for some reason) don’t apply to the testing of conventional medical treatment (which is known to be spurious, often dishonest, and sometimes outright corrupt). Scientific Evidence supporting the Effectiveness of Homeopathy as a Medical Therapy Conventional medicine is failing because its drugs and vaccines are proving to be both harmful and ineffective. This makes the supporters and beneficiaries of the pharmaceutical industry even more determined to undermine homeopathy. Their fervour increases the more they realise that fewer people are willing to submit themselves to their drugs, and instead are turning to homeopathy, and other natural therapies, for their health care. So homeopathy is indeed a pseudo-science - for anyone who does not have the wit or willingness to look critically, and compare the medical outcomes obtained by the two main medical therapies used throughout the world.

Thanks for the A2A.  Good question! Homeopathy could be the poster child for pseudoscience. Wikipedia lists the following as characteristics of Pseudoscience:  "a claim, belief or practice presented as scientific, but which does not adhere to the scientific method... a use of vague, contradictory, exaggerated or unprovable claims; an over-reliance on confirmation rather than rigorous attempts at refutation; a lack of openness to evaluation by other experts in the field; and a general absence of systematic practices when rationally developing theories."  We can all agree that homeopathy presents itself as a science. That it does not adhere to the scientific method is for the below points to show. Homeopathy makes vague claims, with arguments that we don't know how it works, just that it does. Exaggerated claims have been made about homeopathy curing conditions that are generally considered incurable, chronic, etc. Excuses are made that render it unprovable one way or another - in homeopathy's case, the claim is often that they can't do RCTs as homeopathy is individualised. Over-reliance on confirmation rather than refutation; a former homeopath who used the traditional method of refutation rather than confirmation  (Edzard Ernst) is now hounded by alt-med advocates  for actually doing science. The horror!Lack of openness to evaluation by others: governmental studies, systematic reviews, Cochrane reviews and meta-analyses is conducted by scientists are rejected again and again by homeopaths. Why?The unwillingness to apply conventional best-practice systematic approaches to homeopathy, as mentioned above - it just works and it is "individualised medicine" are used as excuses, and then RCTs and meta-analysis which do use systematic practices - but don't show homeopathy working - are, for some reason, ignored. This article lists further characteristics of pseudoscience:  It's dogmatic. Homeopathy starts with the principle that it works and research in the field tends to be seeking proof, rather than, as mentioned above, refutation. When dogma is challenged, as mentioned re Ernst, they are personally attacked, rather than embraced as testing the theory. The idea is aimed directly at the publicPharmaceutical medicine has to be tested and shown to work, passing a very high bar set by regulators and then pharma companies have to persuade doctors to prescribe most medicines by again proving they are better than the alternative. Homeopathy is aimed at the public, can be purchased unlicensed over the counter and has not had to pass this high bar. Ideas that are non-testable - see RCTs aboveVerbose language and prose / Conceptual hijackingThe use of verbose scientific-sounding language in a poorly-defined context, or hijacking of unrelated field. For example, "energy" and "quantum".Confirmation-bias (selective evidence) - see meta-analysis etc, above. Metaphorical/analogy driven thinkingSee "quantum", above. Also various analogies about vaccinations. But scientific arguments should be based on evidence, of course. Anecdotes as evidence"It worked for my mum/my patient/etc." Then why doesn't it seem to work when tested? Anecdote isn't evidence. Lack of explicit mechanismsHow does homeopathy work again? I've never read any clear or explicit mechanism by which water could retain memory of a molecule it no longer contains, never mind how it could act in the body. Special pleading (elusive evidence) - see RCTs above, again. Conspiracy theorySee: claims that big pharma is somehow suppressing homeopathy.

Homeopathy is not pseudoscience. It's quackery,pure and simple. Many people in this world take homeopathic remedies and claim that it has cured them. I once ate a guava and next day my fever went away,so that means guava made the fever go away……NO. This is not how association and causation are established in medical science. The gold standard of today's medicine is evidence based medicine. There are certain criterias given by the great surgeon general of USA sir Bradford Hill that must be fulfilled to establish causation. 1)TEMPORAL ASSOCIATION Does the suspected cause precede the observed effect?A causal association requires that exposure to a putative cause must precede temporarily the onset of a disease which it is purported to produce to allow for any necessary period of induction and latency. For example-smoking and lung cancer. 2) STRENGTH OF ASSOCIATION Is there a dose-respone , duration-response relationship? As with the above example- number of cigarettes and relative risk of developing lung cancer. 3) SPECIFICITY OF ASSOCIATION One to one relationship between cause and effect. Various diseases are multi factorial in origin so this criteria may not always be satisfied. 4) CONSISTENCY OF ASSOCIATION Results are replicated in different settings and by different methods. 5) BIOLOGICAL PLAUSIBILITY Association agrees with current understanding of the response of cells , tissues,organs,and systems of stimuli. 6) COHERENCE OF ASSOCIATION Coherence with known facts that are relevant. The best way to establish whether a certain drug or organism or stimulus causes disease or treats it is to conduct a double blind randomised controlled trial. If you look carefully, homeopathic remedies turn the second criteria upside down.The more diluted the solution,the more will be it's effect and potency. It's highly illogical and unscientific. No RCT or peer reviewed journal has ever reported an effect of homeopathic remedies. It's a big big lie .

Yes. It fits the simple definition well. It’s a claim that fails utterly when examined using established scientific method. Professor Paul Glasziou of Bond University recently headed a team of experts from the National Health and Medical Research Council who examined all the independent scientific trials of homeopathy. Their results were conclusive A total of 57 systematic reviews, containing the 176 individual studies, focused on 68 different health conditions - and found there to be no evidence homeopathy was more effective than placebo on any. 176 individual studies were conducted and not a single one of them found any evidence that homeopathy was effective in any way. That’s as damning as scientific examination gets. That’s game over, goodnight nurse, pack up and go home. The verdict is in. It’s psuedoscience. But of course it will continue because people are getting rich of it. Something really needs to be done. If someone wants to pay money to a psychic who tells them that their dead relatives love them then I think they’re wasting their cash but it’s their own business and their right. But people shouldn’t be able to falsely advertise a product as having medicinal properties when science has proven time and time again that they’re not telling the truth. Homoeopathy officially doesn’t work

It depends on your definition of pseudoscience. In a pure Popperian definition, it is not, because it makes falsifiable claims — and these claims have been well and truly falsified! On these terms, it is very firmly in the realm of “bad science”. On a broader definition of pseudoscience, which would include a lot of bad science, then yes, it does fit the definition.

Homeopathic medicines are placebo at best and potentially harmful when they are used to replace the real thing. You don’t have to prove it. A large meta study has already done so. The whole concept is nonsense.
